facts.text: Appeal is Civil Appeal No. 433 of 1957.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 433 of 1957. Appeal from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and order dated August 24, 1956, of Rajasthan High Court in Civil Misc. Case No. 17 of 1955.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated August 24, 1956, of the Rajasthan High Court at Jodhpur in Civil Misc. Case No. 17 of 1955.

facts.text: Appellant is resident of former independent State of Udaipur.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant is a resident of what was once the independent State of Udaipur. There was in that State a Company called the

facts.text: Mewar Industries, Ltd. registered under law in force in Udaipur State.

anchor.surface_text: There was in that State a Company called the Mewar Industries, Ltd., registered under the provisions of the law in force in that State,

facts.text: Appellant held 266 shares in Mewar Industries Ltd.

anchor.surface_text: and the appellant held 266 shares in that Company.

facts.text: Company went into liquidation on January 18, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: On January 18, 1950, the Company went into liquidation, and on April 22, 1950, the

facts.text: Liquidator distributed assets to shareholders on April 22, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: liquidator distributed a portion of the assets among the shareholders, and the appellant was paid a sum of Rs. 26,000 under this distribution.

facts.text: Appellant received Rs. 26,000 from liquidator on April 22, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: the appellant was paid a sum of Rs. 26,000 under this distribution. It is common ground that this sum represents the undistributed

facts.text: Rs. 26,000 represents undistributed profits accrued during six accounting years preceding liquidation. (common ground)

anchor.surface_text: It is common ground that this sum represents the undistributed profits of the Company which had accrued during the six accounting years preceding the liquidation.

facts.text: No law imposing tax on income in Udaipur State before Indian Finance Act, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: It should be mentioned that there was in the State of Udaipur no law imposing tax on income, and that it was only under the Indian Finance Act, 1950 that the

facts.text: Indian Finance Act, 1950 came into force on April 1, 1950, making residents of Rajasthan liable to income tax.

anchor.surface_text: residents of the State of Rajasthan, in which the State of Udaipur had merged, became liable for the first time to pay tax on their income. That Act came into force on April 1, 1950.

facts.text: Concerned with assessment for year 1951-52, previous year 1950-51.

anchor.surface_text: We are concerned in these proceedings with the assessment of tax for the year 1951-52, and that, under s. 3 of the Act, has to be on the income of the previous year, i.e., 1950-51.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer held Rs. 26,000 as dividend u/s 2(6A)(c) by order dated July 3, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: By his order dated July 3, 1952, the Income-tax Officer held that this was dividend as defined in s. 2(6A)(c) of the Act and included it in the taxable income of the appellant in the year of account.

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner confirmed assessment on January 12, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant took this order in appeal to the Appellate Assistant Commissioner who by his order dated January 12, 1953, confirmed the assessment.

facts.text: Appellate Tribunal dismissed appeal on November 10, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: There was a further appeal by the appellant to the Appellate Tribunal, who also dismissed it on November 10, 1953.

facts.text: Tribunal referred question to High Court on application of appellant.

anchor.surface_text: On the application of the appellant, the Appellate Tribunal referred the following question for the decision of the High Court Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of this case, the aforesaid sum of Rs. 26,000 was liable to be taxed in the assessees hands as dividend within the meaning of that term in s. 2(6A)(c) of the Indian Income-tax Act.

facts.text: Rajasthan High Court answered reference in affirmative on August 24, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: The reference was heard by Wanchoo, C. J. and Modi, J. who by their judgment dated August 24, 1956, answered it in the affirmative.

facts.text: Profits distributed accumulated during years 1943-44 to 1948-49. (not in dispute)

anchor.surface_text: It is not in dispute that the profits which were distributed had been accumulated during the years 1943-44 to 1948-49, i.e., during the six years preceding the liquida- tion.

facts.text: Dispute on whether 1943-44 to 1948-49 are 'previous years' under s.2(6A)(c).

anchor.surface_text: The point in controversy is whether those years can be said to be previous years within s. 2(6A)(c) of the Act.

facts.text: Supreme Court appeal preferred on certificate under s.66A(2).

anchor.surface_text: It is against this judgment that the present appeal has been preferred on a certificate granted by the High Court under s. 66A(2) of the Act.

facts.text: Court holds Rs. 26,000 is dividend u/s 2(6A)(c) and chargeable to tax.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, we hold that the sum of Rs. 26,000 received by the appellant on April 22, 1950, as dividend as defined in s. 2(6A)(c) of the Act and is chargeable to tax.

facts.text: Whether Mewar Industries Ltd. was a 'company' under I.T. Act is disputed.

anchor.surface_text: whether the Mewar Industries Ltd., is a Company as defined in the Indian Income-tax Act is itself a question over which the parties are in controversy.

facts.text: Mewar Industries Ltd. was assessable or assessed as company for year ending March 31, 1948. (respondent contention)

anchor.surface_text: It is contended for the respondent that the Mewar Industries Ltd., was an association which was assessable as a Company for the year ending March 31, 1948, and that it was, in fact, assessed but the appellant disputes this.

facts.text: Indian Companies Act came into operation in Udaipur on April 1, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: the Indian Companies Act came into operation in the Udaipur territory on April 1, 1951, only by force of the Part B States (Laws) Act, 1951

issues.text: Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of this case, the aforesaid sum of Rs. 26,000 was liable to be taxed in the assessees hands as dividend within the meaning of that term in s. 2 6A c of the Indian Income-tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of this case, the aforesaid sum of Rs. 26,000 was liable to be taxed in the assessees hands as dividend within the meaning of that term in s. 2 6A c of the Indian Income-tax Act.

issues.text: whether the sum of Rs. 26,000 received by the appellant on April 22, 1950, is dividend as defined in s. 2 6A c of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: The sole point for determination in this appeal is whether the sum of Rs. 26,000 received by the appellant on April 22, 1950, is dividend as defined in. s. 2 6A c of the Act.

issues.text: whether those years can be said to be previous years within s. 2 6A c of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: The point in controversy is whether those years can be said to be previous years within s. 2 6A c of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: The question is which of these two interpretations is the right one to be put on the language of s. 2 6A c .

arguments.claim: Rs. 26,000 received by appellant is not dividend under s. 2(6A)(c) because profits accumulated in 1943-44 to 1948-49 are not 'six previous years' as no assessment years existed before 1950, hence no previous years under s. 2(11)

anchor.surface_text: The appellant contends that previous year as defined in s. 2 l 1  of the Act means the year which is previous to the assessment year, that accordingly when there is no year of assessment, there can be no previous year, that construing the words six previous years in s. 2 6A  c  in the light of the definition of previous year in s. 2 l 1  of the Act, the years 1943-44 to 1948-49 cannot be held to be previous years, because the Indian Income-tax Act came into force in the State of Rajasthan only on April 1, 1950, and prior to that date there was at no time any law imposing tax on income in the State of Udaipur, that there was therefore no year of assessment, and that, in consequence, the sum of Rs. 26,000 received by the appellant on April 22, 1950, is not a dividend as defined in s. 2 6A  c .

court_response_anchor.surface_text: definitions given in s. 2 of the Act are, as provided therein, to govern unless there is anything repugnant in the subject or companytext . Now, the

arguments.court_reasoning: Repugnant to context of s. 2(6A)(c) as cannot have six previous years to one assessment year; previous years mean accounting years preceding liquidation

arguments.claim: Expression 'six previous years' in s. 2(6A)(c) means six consecutive accounting years preceding liquidation, not tied to assessment years under s. 2(11)

anchor.surface_text: The contention of the respondent which has been accepted by the Income-tax authorities and by the learned Judges in the Court below is that the expression six previous years is used in s. 2 6A  c  not in the technical and restricted sense in which the words previous year are used in s. 2 11  of the Act, and that, in the context, it means six consecutive accounting years preceding the liquidation of the company.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: of this Act. It is companytended for the respondent that the Mewar Industries Ltd., was an association which was assessable as a Company for the year

arguments.court_reasoning: Language and policy support: repugnant to apply s.2(11); means company accounting years

arguments.claim: Definition of 'previous year' in s. 2(11) applies to 'six previous years' in s. 2(6A)(c) unless clearly repugnant, which requires showing absurd results

anchor.surface_text: The argument of Mr. Sharma for the appellant is that s. 2 11  having defined the meaning which the expression previous year has to bear in the Act, that meaning should, according to the well-settled rules of construction, be given to those words wherever they might occur in the statute, and that that is the meaning which must be given to the words six previous years in s. 2 6A  c . It is to be noticed that the definitions given in s. 2 of the Act are, as provided therein, to govern unless there is anything repugnant in the subject or context . Now, the appellant contends that the words unless there is anything repugnant are much more emphatic than words such as unless the subject or context otherwise requires , and that before the definition in the interpretation clause is rejected as repugnant to the subject or context, it must be clearly shown that if that is adopted, it will lead to absurd or anomalous results.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: e appellant that if that was what was intended by the legislature, that was sufficiently expressed by the words preceding the liquidation , and that t

arguments.court_reasoning: Rule accepted but application repelled as repugnant in context

arguments.claim: Under s. 13(2) General Clauses Act, singular 'previous year' in s. 2(11) includes plural 'previous years' for s. 2(6A)(c)

anchor.surface_text: It was argued that under s. 13 2  of the General Clauses Act, 1897, words in the singular should be read as including the plural, and that, therefore, the definition of previous year in s. 2 l 1  could be read as meaning previous years .

court_response_anchor.surface_text: might have been accumulated, in the former such profits would be dividend only in so far as they came out of profits accumulated within six years prio

arguments.court_reasoning: Repugnant to subject and context; nullifies definition

arguments.claim: Six previous years can be each previous to the next following year if that was assessment year, consistent with s. 2(11)

anchor.surface_text: It was then suggested that all the six previous years might be regarded as previous each to the next following year if that was itself a year of assessment, and that such a construction would, consistently with the contention of the appellant, give full effect to the definition in s. 2 11  of the Act.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: any for ascertainment of profits and loss might be different from the calendar years, and the words previous year would be more appropriate to company

arguments.court_reasoning: Overlooks that only one previous year per assessment year; makes no sense

arguments.claim: Applying s. 2(11) definition to 'six previous years' in s. 2(6A)(c) is repugnant as contradicts having six previous years to one assessment year

anchor.surface_text: Turning to the language of s. 2 II , we have this that according to the definition contained therein, previous year is the year which is previous to the year of assessment, and that means that there can be only one previous year to a given year of assessment. When s. 2 6A   c  speaks of six previous years, it is obvious that it uses the expression previous year in a sense different from that which is given to it in s. 2 l 1 , because it would be a contradiction in terms to speak of six previous years in relation to any specific assessment year.

arguments.claim: Policy of s. 2(6A)(c) requires 'six previous years' to mean cycle of six accounting years preceding liquidation to catch accumulated profits

anchor.surface_text: An examination of the policy underlying s. 2 6A  c  also leads to the same conclusion. When a company makes profits and instead of distributing them as dividend accumulates them from year to year and at a later date distributes them to the shareholders, the amounts so distributed would be dividend under s. 2 6A   a , but when a company which has so accumulated the profits goes into liquidation before declaring a dividend and the liquidator distributes those profits to the shareholders, it was held in Commissioners o Inland Revenue v. Burrell  1  that such distribution was not a dividend because when once liquidation intervenes, there was no question of distribution of dividends, and all the assets of the company remaining after the discharge of its obligations were surplus divisible among  1   1924  9 T.C. 27- the shareholders as capital.

arguments.claim: Mewar Industries Ltd. not a 'company' under s. 2(6) as Indian Companies Act applied only from 1951; distribution not dividend under s. 2(6A)(c)

anchor.surface_text: The appellant sought to raise one other contention, and that is that the Indian Companies Act came into operation in the Udaipur territory on April 1, 1951, only by force of the Part B States (Laws) Act  111 of 1951 , that during the relevant period the Mewar Industries Ltd. was not a company as defined in s. 2 5A  of the Act, and that therefore the distribution of assets made by that Company on April 22, 1950, could not be held to be a dividend as defined in s. 2  6A   c .

arguments.claim: Mewar Industries Ltd. was an association assessable/assessed as company for year ending March 31, 1948 under s. 2(6)

anchor.surface_text: It is contended for the respondent that the Mewar Industries Ltd., was an association which was assessable as a Company for the year ending March 31, 1948, and that it was, in fact, assessed but the appellant disputes this.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ded for it is companyrelated to a year of assessment immediately following, but it is number necess

arguments.court_reasoning: Disputed question of fact; cannot be raised at this stage

arguments.claim: 'Previous years' in s. 2(6A)(c) connotes company's financial/accounting years preceding liquidation, not calendar years

anchor.surface_text: But the words preceding years would have meant calendar years, whereas the accounting years of the company for ascertainment of profits and loss might be different from the calendar years, and the words previous year would be more appropriate to connote the financial year of a company.

arguments.claim: Rs. 26,000 is dividend under s. 2(6A)(c) as profits from six previous accounting years 1943-44 to 1948-49

anchor.surface_text: In the present case, as the Company went into liquidation on January 18, 1950, excluding the current year which commenced on April 1, 1949, the six previous years will be the years 1943-44 to 1948-49.

arguments.claim: Expression 'previous year' can mean completed accounting year preceding contingency, not always tied to assessment year (citing Srinivasan)

anchor.surface_text: Mahajan, J. delivering the judgment of the Court observed The expression previous year substantially means an accounting year comprised of a full period of twelve months and usually corresponding to a financial year preceding the financial year of assessment. ... In a certain context it may well mean a completed accounting year immediately preceding the happening of a contingency.

holdings.text: we hold that the sum of Rs. 26,000 received by the appellant on April 22, 1950, is dividend as defined in s. 2(6A)(c) of the Act and is chargeable to tax

anchor.surface_text: In the result, we hold that the sum of Rs. 26,000 received by the appellant on April 22, 1950, as dividend as defined in s. 2(6A)(c) of the Act and is chargeable to tax.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distribution of accumulated profits from six accounting years preceding liquidation qualifies as dividend under s.2(6A)(c); s.2(11) definition repugnant

holdings.text: it would be repugnant to the definition of dividend in s. 2(6A)(c) to import into the words six previous years the definition of previous year in s. 2(11) of the Act

anchor.surface_text: We are satisfied that it would be repugnant to the definition of dividend in s. 2 6A  c  to import into the words six previous years the definition of previous year in s. 2 l 1  of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.2(11) allows only one previous year per assessment year; contradicts 'six previous years' for one liquidation

holdings.text: the expression six previous years is used in s. 2(6A)(c) not in the technical and restricted sense in which the words previous year are used in s. 2(11) of the Act, and that, in the context, it means six consecutive accounting years preceding the liquidation of the company

anchor.surface_text: The contention of the respondent which has been accepted by the Income-tax authorities and by the learned Judges in the Court below is that the expression six previous years is used in s. 2 6A  c  not in the technical and restricted sense in which the words previous year are used in s. 2 11  of the Act, and that, in the context, it means six consecutive accounting years preceding the liquidation of the company.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Language, context, and policy require accounting years preceding liquidation to prevent tax avoidance on old accumulations

holdings.text: as the Company went into liquidation on January 18, 1950, excluding the current year which commenced on April 1, 1949, the six previous years will be the years 1943-44 to 1948-49

anchor.surface_text: In the present case, as the Company went into liquidation on January 18, 1950, excluding the current year which commenced on April 1, 1949, the six previous years will be the years 1943-44 to 1948-49.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Application of interpreted 'six previous years' to facts of liquidation date

holdings.text: that is not a question which was referred for the opinion of the High Court under s.66(1) of the Act nor is it even dealt with by the Tribunal and therefore cannot be said to arise out of its order. Moreover... As the point turns on disputed question of fact, it cannot be allowed to be raised at this stage

anchor.surface_text: But that is not a question which was referred for the opinion of the High Court under s. 66 1  of the Act nor is it even dealt with by the Tribunal and therefore cannot be said to arise out of its order. Moreover, whether the Mewar Industries Ltd., is a Company as defined in the Indian Income-tax Act is itself a question over which the parties are in controversy.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Issue not part of s.66(1) reference, not in Tribunal order, involves disputed facts

precedents.case_name: Girdhardas Co. Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax
precedents.cited_proposition: current profits of a company in liquidation distributed to shareholders are not dividend within s. 2(6A)(c)

precedents.citation: Commissioner of Income-tax, Madras v. K. Srinivasan and K. Gopalan

anchor.surface_text: Commissioner of Income-tax, Madras v. K. Srinivasan and K. Gopalan  1 . There, the point for decision was as to the interpretation to be put on the words end of the previous year in s. 25, sub-ss.  3  and  4  of the Act which dealt with discontinuance of or succession to a business, and it was held that the expression previous year in those provisions meant an accounting year expiring immediately preceding the date of discontinuance or succession.

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax, Madras v. K. Srinivasan and K. Gopalan
precedents.cited_proposition: previous year can mean an accounting year immediately preceding the happening of a contingency, not necessarily related to assessment year
precedents.cited_holding: the expression previous year in s. 25(3) and (4) meant an accounting year expiring immediately preceding the date of discontinuance or succession

anchor.surface_text: Now, it should be mentioned that when a companypany in liquidation distributes its current profits,, that would also be number dividend as held in Burrells case  1 , and the law to that extent has been left untouched by s. 2 6A  c .

precedents.cited_proposition: distribution of current profits by company in liquidation is not dividend
